keyTakeAways: The new White House ballroom, valued at $250 million, is being funded by a mix of personal and corporate donations, sparking ethical concerns.
YouTube contributed $22 million through a legal settlement with Trump over the Capitol riot, making it the only confirmed donor so far.
A dinner on October 15, 2025, brought together executives from major corporations including Blackstone, Microsoft, Amazon, Google, Palantir, Coinbase, and Lockheed Martin.

Potential donors, including Woody Johnson and the Glazers (owners of the New York Jets and Tampa Bay Buccaneers and Manchester United), were present at the event, raising questions about corporate influence.
Donors may receive public recognition, such as names etched into the ballroom structure, suggesting a form of political visibility.
The White House insists the renovation does not cost taxpayers and will be used by future administrations, but legal experts like Richard Painter warn it may amount to a 'pay-to-play' scheme.

Richard Painter, former chief ethics lawyer in the Bush administration, criticizes the project as an 'ethics nightmare' due to the potential for corporate access to the administration in exchange for financial support.
The ballroom's capacity has been updated from 650 to 999, indicating a significant increase in scale and possibly greater potential for fundraising.
The Trust for the National Mall is managing the donations, handling fundraising for White House and National Mall projects.
The project's funding model raises concerns about transparency, as no official list of donors or contributions has been released.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The construction of a new $250 million White House ballroom, set to hold 999 people, has ignited ethical concerns over who is funding it and whether it constitutes a 'pay-to-play' scheme. While President Donald Trump claims personal and donor contributions, only YouTube has officially pledged $22 million through a legal settlement with Trump over the January 6 Capitol riot. A donor dinner on October 15, 2025, brought together executives from major corporations including Blackstone, Microsoft, Amazon, Google, and Palantir, as well as sports franchises like the Jets and Buccaneers. Critics, including former ethics lawyer Richard Painter, argue that the funding model could allow corporations to gain access to the administration in exchange for donations. The Trust for the National Mall manages the donations, but no official list of contributors has been released. The White House maintains that the project does not cost taxpayers and will be used by future administrations, but legal experts warn it may push ethical boundaries by enabling corporate influence over policy.
title: Who is paying for Donald Trump's new White House ballroom?
